column4: is there a seperate trash for root? i just deleted 12.1 gigs under a sudo'd nautilus and it didn't free up 12.1 gigs
No.
erm.  O dear.  Don't do that.
drop to a terminal.  'df -h' should show free space / utilization by partition.
i just did bad things, didn't i...
Running GUI file management tools as root is ... frowned on.
same thing. i guess being too lazy to rm -r the folders screwed me over?

'df' and 'du' can trace down where the space is.  If you deleted files which are open by other tools, then they may still exist.  Or nautilus may have tried to help you by saving stuff in trash.  Yeah, you probably want to find out  where root's trash is.
I don't use nautilus period so I don't know off the top of my head.
duly noted. what do you use? =]
bash ;-)
If I want some sort of interactive tool for file management, 'mc', based on an old Norton utility.
lol. my command-fu isn't good enough to do things like matching pattern deletes =)
find . -name \*pattern\*
| xargs rm ?
... is a good start.  You can slice and dice it a bit from there.  If you're not sure you want to delete that automatically (you could do ... yeah, xargs), you can write to a file.
... then edit the file manually, and feed *that* to xargs.
xargs rm <file
bash is so cool. i keep on meaning to learn it better.
Use it.  Buy "UNIX Power Tools"
